awd_titl_txt: EAGER: MAKER: Nano-Makerspace to Make and Explore in the World of the Small
awd_abstract_narration:
ABSTRACT

This project will expose a broad community of high school students and teachers, undergraduate students and the public to the nanoscale  "World of the Small" as well as the rules that govern the physical world at the nanoscale level. These rules are very different from what we generally experience in our everyday lives. The tools, know-how, and environment to explore at the nanoscale have been generally out of reach of typical Makerspaces. Institutions with such capabilities often limit facilities to graduate students and research scientists. While this supports excellent research, it does not support the Maker environment of informal, process-oriented approaches to self-discovery of interests and skills. 

The proposed project will provide the tools, environment, and the knowledge to "Makers" to explore the "World of the Small" by applying the principles of Making. Three research questions will be addressed in the course of the project: (i) What is the impact of the Nano-Maker space / mobile Nano lab exposure on students' ability to grasp "nano" and "quantum concepts" (ii) What is the impact across different student populations of introducing Nano-Makerspaces?, and (iii) How can the findings from the project be applied to positively impact traditional educational approaches?

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to apply the highly informal learning modalities of “Making” to introduce 9-12, undergraduate, and teachers to nanoscience concepts. To accomplish these goals a “Nano-Makerspace” and a series of mobile nanoscience laboratories was created to introduce students and teachers to the “World of the Small”. The environment created because of this project provided the space, access to nanofabrication and metrology tools, know-how, and encouragement to allow “Makers” to explore and learn nanoscience concepts.

An outcome of this project was to create a Nano-Makerspace. Seeded by the effort of this project additional funding from the state of Massachusetts and the University were secured to renovate and install a 600 sq.ft. class 1000 cleanroom which houses nanofabrication and metrology tools. This cleanroom facility is equipped with a scanning electron microscope with nanolithography capability, ebeam and sputtering deposition tools, mask aligner, spin coater, optical microscope, atomic force microscope, wirebonder, and probe station. Much of the equipment was secured second hand and setup by undergraduate and high school students. Every year of this program approximately 10 students worked in the Nano-Makerspace. This cleanroom facility is in the engineering department at the University of Massachusetts Boston that is an undergraduate only department with the purpose to serve students to introduce them to nanoscience concepts. During this project we developed working with active students’ educational modules to train new users to the equipment in the cleanroom as well as nanofabrication and nanotechnology concepts.

 

During this project a series of mobile nano-laboratories was created to introduce students to nanotechnology concepts. The purpose of these mobile nano laboratories was to bring nanotechnology equipment to the students in high schools. The project supported the purchase of an atomic force microscope which is a small desktop unit that can be connected to a laptop computer. A series of modules aligned with high school standards was developed utilizing the atomic force microscope and mobile nano laboratories were delivered to students at two public school districts and involved the participation of three science teachers. During this project COVID19 pandemic occurred and the mobile nano laboratories were converted to a remote modality and were delivered over zoom. Due to the nature of the technology of the atomic force microscope we were able to develop mobile nano laboratories that allowed students to control the microscope virtually over a zoom session.

An outcome of this project was to assess the application-based mobile nonlaboratory module which was developed and delivered. Our study focused on exploring student readiness to unpack unfamiliar nanoscience and nanotechnology (NST) concepts, and the effects engagement with NST had on student attitudes towards STEM subjects. Participants included a total of three science teachers and 169, grade 8 and 9 students from two public school districts from a northeastern state of the USA over two years. Data was collected and used from students who consented for the study. The NST learning module was developed in three phases, beginning with an introductory session to discuss module content and design. We then designed a module for implementation. Drawing from results from the pilot module and teacher inputs, we revised the pilot module for this study. Surveys, content questionnaires, student reflections, and classroom videos were collected for analysis. Students demonstrated conceptual understanding of the working of the AFM after working closely with the tool. Our data highlights students’ readiness to unpack unfamiliar NST concepts and the observation of an increase in students’ attitudes towards STEM subjects and careers, and an increase in the number of students who plan to take advanced STEM courses.
